title: Sentence Correctness
description: Test your English grammar by identifying correct and incorrect sentences. Practice with real-world examples.

exercises.sentence: A lot of people is coming.
exercises.explanation: A lot is plural. Corrected: A lot of people are coming.

exercises.sentence: A lot of people went to the concert.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: A number of students are absent.
exercises.explanation: A number is plural in this context.

exercises.sentence: Alot of people went to the concert.
exercises.explanation: A lot is two words. Corrected: A lot of people went to the concert.

exercises.sentence: At the present time, I am busy.
exercises.explanation: Verbose. Corrected: I am busy now.

exercises.sentence: At what time will you arrive?
exercises.explanation: Correct usage of preposition.

exercises.sentence: Between you and I, this is a secret.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect pronoun case. Corrected: Between you and me, this is a secret.

exercises.sentence: Bring the book to me.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: Can I borrow your pencil?
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: Can I lend your pencil?
exercises.explanation: Wrong word use. Corrected: Can you lend me your pencil?

exercises.sentence: Can I please borrow your pencil?
exercises.explanation: Correct syntax.

exercises.sentence: Can you please borrow me a pencil?
exercises.explanation: Borrow is wrong word. Corrected: Can you please lend me a pencil?

exercises.sentence: Can you please lend me your pencil?
exercises.explanation: Correct syntax.

exercises.sentence: Despite of the rain, we went for a walk.
exercises.explanation: Redundant preposition. Corrected: Despite the rain, we went for a walk.

exercises.sentence: Do you have patients?
exercises.explanation: Wrong word use. Corrected: Do you have patience?

exercises.sentence: Each of the players try their best.
exercises.explanation: Subject-verb agreement error. "Each" takes a singular verb. Corrected: Each of the players tries their best.

exercises.sentence: Each of the students are responsible.
exercises.explanation: Agreement error is "is" not "are". Corrected: Each of the students is responsible.

exercises.sentence: Each students need a pencil.
exercises.explanation: Student should be plural. Corrected: Each student needs a pencil.

exercises.sentence: Either John or his friends is going to pick her up.
exercises.explanation: Subject-verb agreement error. The verb should agree with the noun closest to it. Corrected: Either John or his friends are going to pick her up.

exercises.sentence: Either John or Mary are coming.
exercises.explanation: The first word of the pair is the correct one to use in the agreement. Corrected: Either John or Mary is coming.

exercises.sentence: Either of those options work for me.
exercises.explanation: Singular verb use. Corrected: Either of those options works for me.

exercises.sentence: Every child want a toy.
exercises.explanation: Child should be singular. Corrected: Every child wants a toy.

exercises.sentence: Every student have to take the test.
exercises.explanation: Every is singular. Corrected: Every student has to take the test.

exercises.sentence: Everyday I go to school.
exercises.explanation: Should be "every day", not "everyday" (adjective). Corrected: Every day I go to school.

exercises.sentence: Everyone are going to the party.
exercises.explanation: Subject-verb agreement. "Everyone" is singular. Corrected: Everyone is going to the party.

exercises.sentence: Everyone are welcome.
exercises.explanation: The singular use of every. Corrected: Everyone is welcome.

exercises.sentence: Everyone but he went to the party.
exercises.explanation: Pronoun case error. Corrected: Everyone but him went to the party.

exercises.sentence: Everyone is happy.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: Give it to John and I.
exercises.explanation: Pronoun error. Corrected: Give it to John and me.

exercises.sentence: He always has been on time.
exercises.explanation: Order is bad. Corrected: He has always been on time.

exercises.sentence: He don't like coffee.
exercises.explanation: Subject-verb agreement error. Corrected: He doesn't like coffee.

exercises.sentence: He done a good job.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect verb form. Corrected: He did a good job.

exercises.sentence: He drive good.
exercises.explanation: Should be "well" (adverb) because it modifies the verb "drive". Corrected: He drives well.

exercises.sentence: He felt good after the workout.
exercises.explanation: Describes how he felt.

exercises.sentence: He gave the book to Mary and I.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect pronoun case. Corrected: He gave the book to Mary and me.

exercises.sentence: He give the book to Mary and I.
exercises.explanation: The correct case is "me" not "I". Corrected: He give the book to Mary and me.

exercises.sentence: He has ate all of his dinner.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect verb form. Corrected: He has eaten all of his dinner.

exercises.sentence: He have a new car.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect subject-verb agreement. Corrected: He has a new car.

exercises.sentence: He insisted to pay for the meal.
exercises.explanation: Wrong word use. Corrected: He insisted on paying for the meal.

exercises.sentence: He is a good swimmer.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: He is a great principle.
exercises.explanation: Wrong word use. Corrected: He is a great principal.

exercises.sentence: He is a honest man.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect article usage. Corrected: He is an honest man.

exercises.sentence: He is a real good player.
exercises.explanation: Use "really" to modify an adjective. Corrected: He is a really good player.

exercises.sentence: He is a unique person.
exercises.explanation: Because unique sounds like "you-neek" then a is correct here.

exercises.sentence: He is addicted from coffee.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect preposition. Corrected: He is addicted to coffee.

exercises.sentence: He is as tall as me.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: He is cleaning the house.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: He is dancing.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: He is depending of his parents.
exercises.explanation: The preposition "on." Corrected: He is depending on his parents.

exercises.sentence: He is different than me.
exercises.explanation: Different from is generally preferred over "different than". Corrected: He is different from me.

exercises.sentence: He is driving fastly.
exercises.explanation: No such word. Corrected: He is driving fast.

exercises.sentence: He is frowning.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: He is going too the store.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage ("too" vs. "to"). Corrected: He is going to the store.

exercises.sentence: He is good at math.
exercises.explanation: Correct sentence.

exercises.sentence: He is good in math.
exercises.explanation: Corrected: He is good at math.

exercises.sentence: He is good.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: He is laying on the bed.
exercises.explanation: The person is lying not laying on the bed. Corrected: He is lying on the bed.

exercises.sentence: He is more taller than his brother.
exercises.explanation: Redundant comparison. Corrected: He is taller than his brother.

exercises.sentence: He is my best friend.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: He is prejudice against them.
exercises.explanation: Not the correct word. Corrected: He is prejudiced against them.

exercises.sentence: He is taller as me.
exercises.explanation: Use the word "than" for comparison. Corrected: He is taller than me.

exercises.sentence: He is taller then me.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word choice. Corrected: He is taller than me.

exercises.sentence: He is the best player on the team.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: He is the fastest runner in the class.
exercises.explanation: Correct sentence.

exercises.sentence: He is the fastest runner of the two boys.
exercises.explanation: Correct sentence.

exercises.sentence: He is the only person who can to do that.
exercises.explanation: Superfluous "to". Corrected: He is the only person who can do that.

exercises.sentence: He is the taller of the two boys.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: He is understanding the problem.
exercises.explanation: Stative verb issue; While less strict than the others, "understand" is generally better in simple tense. Corrected: He understands

exercises.sentence: He is wishing.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: He is writing a letter.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: He laying on the couch.
exercises.explanation: Lying or laying is not the correct form. Corrected: He is lying on the couch.

exercises.sentence: He learned a lot in school.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: He plays the piano very good.
exercises.explanation: Piano is modify by verb. Corrected: He plays the piano very well.

exercises.sentence: He raised the flag.
exercises.explanation: Correct verb usage.

exercises.sentence: He runned to the store.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect verb form. Corrected: He ran to the store.

exercises.sentence: He said that their going to be late.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word choice. Corrected: He said that they're going to be late.

exercises.sentence: He were very happy to see her.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect subject-verb agreement. Corrected: He was very happy to see her.

exercises.sentence: He's car is red.
exercises.explanation: Word usage. Corrected: His car is red.

exercises.sentence: He's use to getting up early.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: He's used to getting up early.

exercises.sentence: Her and me went shopping.
exercises.explanation: Pronoun error. Corrected: She and I went shopping.

exercises.sentence: I always set by the window.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: I always sit by the window.

exercises.sentence: I am adverse to the plan.
exercises.explanation: Correct syntax.

exercises.sentence: I am going to by a new car.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: I am going to buy a new car.

exercises.sentence: I am going to home.
exercises.explanation: Superfluous preposition. Corrected: I am going home.

exercises.sentence: I am going to set down.
exercises.explanation: Set is not the correct verb. Corrected: I am going to sit down.

exercises.sentence: I am going to the park later.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: I am going to the store for buy milk.
exercises.explanation: Use infinitive. Corrected: I am going to the store to buy milk.

exercises.sentence: I am grateful for you.
exercises.explanation: Correct usage. Corrected: I am grateful to you.

exercises.sentence: I am interesting in learning Spanish.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word choice. Corrected: I am interested in learning Spanish.

exercises.sentence: I am laughing.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: I am learning how to play the piano.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: I am listening to music.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: I am looking forward to seeing you.
exercises.explanation: Correct sentence.

exercises.sentence: I am needing help.
exercises.explanation: Stative verb issue; "need" isn't typically used in the continuous. Corrected: I need help.

exercises.sentence: I am not use to this.
exercises.explanation: Correct the word "used". Corrected: I am not used to this.

exercises.sentence: I am seeing the doctor tomorrow.
exercises.explanation: While "see" can be stative, it's commonly used in continuous tense to indicate an appointment. This is correct.

exercises.sentence: I am studying English.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: I am taller as him.
exercises.explanation: Use the word "than" for comparison. Corrected: I am taller than him.

exercises.sentence: I am thinking.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: I am tired.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: I am use to this.
exercises.explanation: Corrected use. Corrected: I am used to this.

exercises.sentence: I am very happy to see you.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: I am very interesting in this book.
exercises.explanation: Wrong adjective. Corrected: I am very interested in this book.

exercises.sentence: I am very much happy to be here.
exercises.explanation: More natural phrasing. Corrected: I am very happy to be here.

exercises.sentence: I am waiting on the bus.
exercises.explanation: Better usage of "for". Corrected: I am waiting for the bus.

exercises.sentence: I appreciate you helping me.
exercises.explanation: Could be re-worded.

exercises.sentence: I appreciate your helping me.
exercises.explanation: Correct syntax.

exercises.sentence: I asked to her.
exercises.explanation: Word error. Corrected: I asked her.

exercises.sentence: I can't except your apology.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: I can't accept your apology.

exercises.sentence: I can't hardly wait.
exercises.explanation: Double negative. Corrected: I can hardly wait. OR I can't wait.

exercises.sentence: I can't here you very well.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: I can't hear you very well.

exercises.sentence: I can't see good.
exercises.explanation: Grammar. Corrected: I can't see well.

exercises.sentence: I could care less.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect idiom; should be "couldn't care less". Corrected: I couldn't care less.

exercises.sentence: I could of helped you.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect usage. Corrected: I could have helped you.

exercises.sentence: I didn't no he was coming.
exercises.explanation: Wrong word use. Corrected: I didn't know he was coming.

exercises.sentence: I don't have no money.
exercises.explanation: Double negative. Corrected: I don't have any money. OR I have no money.

exercises.sentence: I don't have no time to waste.
exercises.explanation: Double negative. Corrected: I don't have any time to waste. or: I have no time to waste.

exercises.sentence: I don't know whether or not to go.
exercises.explanation: Correct usage of "whether".

exercises.sentence: I don't know who to give it to.
exercises.explanation: Word usage and sentence issue. Corrected: I don't know to whom I should give it.

exercises.sentence: I don't remember locking the door.
exercises.explanation: Correct meaning/grammar.

exercises.sentence: I feel badly about what happened.
exercises.explanation: Use "bad" after a linking verb like "feel." Corrected: I feel bad about what happened.

exercises.sentence: I get use to the noise now.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect verb tense. Corrected: I get used to the noise now.

exercises.sentence: I have a dog and a cat.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: I have a less amount of books than you.
exercises.explanation: Correct use of "fewer". Corrected: I have a fewer amount of books than you.

exercises.sentence: I have a lot of patience.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: I have been knowing him for years.
exercises.explanation: Correct syntax. Corrected: I have known him for years.

exercises.sentence: I have been to London before.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: I have less apples than her.
exercises.explanation: Wrong word choice and comparison structure. Corrected: I have fewer apples than she does. or I have fewer apples than her.

exercises.sentence: I have patients in my clinic.
exercises.explanation: Correct sentence.

exercises.sentence: I have seen that movie already.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: I have to many books to carry.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: I have too many books to carry.

exercises.sentence: I have trouble to understanding him.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word use. Corrected: I have trouble understanding him.

exercises.sentence: I have went to Paris.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect verb form. Corrected: I have gone to Paris.

exercises.sentence: I is going to the beach tomorrow.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect subject-verb agreement. Corrected: I am going to the beach tomorrow.

exercises.sentence: I is going to the store.
exercises.explanation: Subject-verb agreement error. Corrected: I am going to the store.

exercises.sentence: I live in the United Kingdom.
exercises.explanation: Correct sentence.

exercises.sentence: I live in United Kingdom.
exercises.explanation: Missing article. Corrected: I live in the United Kingdom.

exercises.sentence: I love to singing in the shower.
exercises.explanation: Verb error. Corrected: I love to sing in the shower.

exercises.sentence: I must lay down now.
exercises.explanation: Not the best usage. Corrected: I must lie down now.

exercises.sentence: I now the answer to the question.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: I know the answer to the question.

exercises.sentence: I now where he lives.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: I know where he lives.

exercises.sentence: I prefer coffee over tea.
exercises.explanation: Correct usage of prefer over.

exercises.sentence: I seen him their yesterday.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: I saw him there yesterday.

exercises.sentence: I seen him yesterday.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect verb tense. Corrected: I saw him yesterday.

exercises.sentence: I seen it with my own eyes.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect verb tense. Corrected: I saw it with my own eyes.

exercises.sentence: I seen the movie last night.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect verb form. Corrected: I saw the movie last night.

exercises.sentence: I use to go there.
exercises.explanation: Did vs. use. Corrected: I used to go there.

exercises.sentence: I use to live there.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect past tense usage. Corrected: I used to live there.

exercises.sentence: I wear everyday clothes to school.
exercises.explanation: Correct usage of "everyday" as an adjective.

exercises.sentence: I went too the store yesterday.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: I went to the store yesterday.

exercises.sentence: I will always remember to visit London.
exercises.explanation: Correct meaning/grammar.

exercises.sentence: I will except your invitation.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: I will accept your invitation.

exercises.sentence: I will learn you how to bake a cake.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: I will teach you how to bake a cake.

exercises.sentence: I will meet you at the library on Tuesday.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: I will never forget visiting London.
exercises.explanation: Correct meaning/grammar.

exercises.sentence: I wish I was taller.
exercises.explanation: Acceptable usage of "was" in a wish.

exercises.sentence: I wish I was you.
exercises.explanation: Correct, informal construction.

exercises.sentence: I wish I were taller.
exercises.explanation: More formal and sometimes preferred usage of "were" in a wish.

exercises.sentence: I wish I were you.
exercises.explanation: Formal construction, also correct.

exercises.sentence: I would of gone if I had known.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word choice. Corrected: I would have gone if I had known.

exercises.sentence: I would of gone to the party, but I was sick.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect use of "of" instead of "have". Corrected: I would have gone to the party, but I was sick.

exercises.sentence: I'm boring.
exercises.explanation: Wrong word use. Corrected: I'm bored.

exercises.sentence: I'm not shore what you mean.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: I'm not sure what you mean.

exercises.sentence: If he was there, he would have helped.
exercises.explanation: Mixed conditional. Corrected: If he had been there, he would have helped.

exercises.sentence: If I was rich, I would travel the world.
exercises.explanation: Conditional sentence using "was" is correct in this context.

exercises.sentence: If I was you, I would study.
exercises.explanation: Correct, informal construction.

exercises.sentence: If I were rich, I would travel the world.
exercises.explanation: Conditional sentence using "were" is also correct.

exercises.sentence: If I were you, I would study.
exercises.explanation: Correct, formal construction.

exercises.sentence: If I would have known, I would have told you.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect conditional sentence structure. Corrected: If I had known, I would have told you.

exercises.sentence: In my opinion, I think that is a good idea.
exercises.explanation: Repetitive. Corrected: I think it's a good idea.

exercises.sentence: Is important to practice every day.
exercises.explanation: Missing word. Corrected: It is important to practice every day.

exercises.sentence: It is a easy question.
exercises.explanation: Corrected article. Corrected: It is an easy question.

exercises.sentence: It is a interesting book.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect article. Should be "an" before a vowel sound. Corrected: It is an interesting book.

exercises.sentence: It is important to be quiet.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: It is kind for you to help.
exercises.explanation: Word usage. Corrected: It is kind of you to help.

exercises.sentence: It is time to decide weather we should go.
exercises.explanation: Wrong word use. Corrected: It is time to decide whether we should go.

exercises.sentence: It is to late to go to the park.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: It is too late to go to the park.

exercises.sentence: It was her whom called.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect pronoun. Corrected: It was she who called.

exercises.sentence: It's a nice day to go swimming to.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word choice. Corrected: It's a nice day to go swimming too.

exercises.sentence: It's a nice whether today.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: It's a nice weather today.

exercises.sentence: It's important too study hard.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: It's important to study hard.

exercises.sentence: It's to cold to go swimming today.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: It's too cold to go swimming today.

exercises.sentence: Its a beautiful day.
exercises.explanation: Contraction error. Corrected: It's a beautiful day.

exercises.sentence: Its important to be quiet.
exercises.explanation: Contraction error. Corrected: It's important to be quiet.

exercises.sentence: Its raining outside, so take an umbrella.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word use. Corrected: It's raining outside, so take an umbrella.

exercises.sentence: John and me are best friends.
exercises.explanation: Pronoun error. Corrected: John and I are best friends.

exercises.sentence: John is a goodly student.
exercises.explanation: Not really a word. Corrected: John is a good student.

exercises.sentence: John lives at Elm Street.
exercises.explanation: Not common. Corrected: John lives on Elm Street.

exercises.sentence: Lay down on the couch.
exercises.explanation: Lay vs. lie. Corrected: Lie down on the couch.

exercises.sentence: Learn to play the guitar.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: Let us buy it, shall we?
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: Let's go to the beach, their is sun and sand.
exercises.explanation: Should be "there". Corrected: Let's go to the beach, there is sun and sand.

exercises.sentence: May I go to the restroom?
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: May I have some water?
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: Me and him went to the movies.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect pronoun case. Corrected: He and I went to the movies.

exercises.sentence: Me and John are going to the store.
exercises.explanation: Word order/pronoun mistake. Corrected: John and I are going to the store.

exercises.sentence: My brother and me went fishing.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect pronoun case. Corrected: My brother and I went fishing.

exercises.sentence: My favorite color is blue.
exercises.explanation: Correct sentence.

exercises.sentence: Neither John nor Mary are coming.
exercises.explanation: The first word of the pair is the correct one to use in the agreement. Corrected: Neither John nor Mary is coming.

exercises.sentence: Neither of them are going.
exercises.explanation: Singular verb use. Corrected: Neither of them is going.

exercises.sentence: Neither the cat nor the dogs is home.
exercises.explanation: Subject-verb agreement error. The verb should agree with the noun closest to it. Corrected: Neither the cat nor the dogs are home.

exercises.sentence: Nobody are perfect.
exercises.explanation: Nobody is singular. Corrected: Nobody is perfect.

exercises.sentence: None of us is going.
exercises.explanation: None can be either singular or plural. Corrected: None of us are going.

exercises.sentence: One of my friend is coming over.
exercises.explanation: Make plural friends. Corrected: One of my friends is coming over.

exercises.sentence: Please put the book over their.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word use. Corrected: Please put the book over there.

exercises.sentence: Please set down.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage; sit vs. set. Corrected: Please sit down.

exercises.sentence: Please, except my apology.
exercises.explanation: Wrong word use. Corrected: Please, accept my apology.

exercises.sentence: Raise your hand if you know the answer.
exercises.explanation: Correct verb usage.

exercises.sentence: Rise and shine!
exercises.explanation: Correct verb usage.

exercises.sentence: Run quickly!
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: Set the book on the table.
exercises.explanation: Correct usage of "set".

exercises.sentence: She always sites that author in her essays.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage; cite vs. site. Corrected: She always cites that author in her essays.

exercises.sentence: She doesn't know nothing about it.
exercises.explanation: Double negative. Corrected: She doesn't know anything about it. OR She knows nothing about it.

exercises.sentence: She don't like chocolate.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect subject-verb agreement. Corrected: She doesn't like chocolate.

exercises.sentence: She enjoys to read books.
exercises.explanation: Correct verb use. Corrected: She enjoys reading books.

exercises.sentence: She goes to school at Monday.
exercises.explanation: Missing preposition. Corrected: She goes to school on Monday.

exercises.sentence: She has all ready finished her homework.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: She has already finished her homework.

exercises.sentence: She has did a good job on the project.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect verb form. Corrected: She has done a good job on the project.

exercises.sentence: She invited John and me to her party.
exercises.explanation: Correct pronoun case.

exercises.sentence: She is a doctor.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: She is a honest person.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect article. Should be "an" before a vowel sound. Corrected: She is an honest person.

exercises.sentence: She is a only child.
exercises.explanation: Correct article. Corrected: She is an only child.

exercises.sentence: She is a very nice person.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: She is afraid of spiders.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: She is always lose her keys.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: She is always losing her keys.

exercises.sentence: She is coming to visit they're house.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: She is coming to visit their house.

exercises.sentence: She is cooking dinner.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: She is eating an apple.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: She is good on math.
exercises.explanation: The best is "at." Corrected: She is good at math.

exercises.sentence: She is hoping.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: She is knowing the answer.
exercises.explanation: Stative verb issue; "know" isn't typically used in the continuous. Corrected: She knows the answer.

exercises.sentence: She is laying on the beach.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: She is lying on the beach.

exercises.sentence: She is more smarter than her sister.
exercises.explanation: Redundant comparison. Corrected: She is smarter than her sister.

exercises.sentence: She is not hear right now.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: She is not here right now.

exercises.sentence: She is not use to the noise.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect idiom. Corrected: She is not used to the noise.

exercises.sentence: She is reading a book.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: She is setting on the chair.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect verb form. Corrected: She is sitting on the chair.

exercises.sentence: She is singing a song.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: She is smiling.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: She is taller then me.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word for comparison ("than" vs. "then"). Corrected: She is taller than me.

exercises.sentence: She is the best singer of the three.
exercises.explanation: Correct sentence.

exercises.sentence: She is the best singer of the two.
exercises.explanation: Use comparative form, better. Corrected: She is the better singer of the two.

exercises.sentence: She is the best student from the class.
exercises.explanation: Wrong preposition. Corrected: She is the best student in the class.

exercises.sentence: She is the only one who know the answer.
exercises.explanation: Subject-verb agreement error. Corrected: She is the only one who knows the answer.

exercises.sentence: She is use to getting up early.
exercises.explanation: Corrected: She is used to getting up early.

exercises.sentence: She is very good at danceing.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect spelling. Corrected: She is very good at dancing.

exercises.sentence: She is very happy to here you.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage and missing preposition. Corrected: She is very happy to hear from you.

exercises.sentence: She is wearing a red dress.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: She laid the book on the table.
exercises.explanation: Correct usage of "laid" as the past tense of "lay".

exercises.sentence: She played the music loudly.
exercises.explanation: Correct.

exercises.sentence: She plays the piano well.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: She teached me how to swim.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect verb form. Corrected: She taught me how to swim.

exercises.sentence: Take the trash out.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: Teach me how to sing.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: That is my principal reason for not going.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: The amount of rain were heavy.
exercises.explanation: Amount is singular. Corrected: The amount of rain was heavy.

exercises.sentence: The baby is crawling to they're mother.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: The baby is crawling to their mother.

exercises.sentence: The baby is very quite.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: The baby is very quiet.

exercises.sentence: The book is laying on the table.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect verb choice; "lay" vs. "lie". Corrected: The book is lying on the table.

exercises.sentence: The book is on the table.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: The building site is dangerous.
exercises.explanation: Correct usage of "site".

exercises.sentence: The cake smells well.
exercises.explanation: Grammar. Corrected: The cake smells good.

exercises.sentence: The car needed washed.
exercises.explanation: Corrected: The car needed to be washed.

exercises.sentence: The car needed washing.
exercises.explanation: Correct syntax.

exercises.sentence: The car needs washing.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: The car stopped sudden.
exercises.explanation: Sudden is an adjective, "suddenly" is an adverb. Corrected: The car stopped suddenly.

exercises.sentence: The cat sat on the mat.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: The children are playing to loud.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: The children are playing too loud.

exercises.sentence: The children played happily in the garden.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: The committee have met.
exercises.explanation: Committee takes singular. Corrected: The committee has met.

exercises.sentence: The cost is to high.
exercises.explanation: The correct form to use is "too". Corrected: The cost is too high.

exercises.sentence: The cost of the repairs where to high.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: The cost of the repairs was too high.

exercises.sentence: The data is being collected.
exercises.explanation: Depending on style, data can be treated as singular.

exercises.sentence: The data is incorrect.
exercises.explanation: Data is often treated as plural. Corrected: The data are incorrect.

exercises.sentence: The dog chased it's tail.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect possessive pronoun. Corrected: The dog chased its tail.

exercises.sentence: The dog wagged it's tail excitedly.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect pronoun. Corrected: The dog wagged its tail excitedly.

exercises.sentence: The dog wagged it's tail.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect use of possessive pronoun. Corrected: The dog wagged its tail.

exercises.sentence: The door was opened by the wind.
exercises.explanation: Correct usage of opened.

exercises.sentence: The effect of the storm was devastating.
exercises.explanation: Correct usage of "effect".

exercises.sentence: The flowers smell so nicely.
exercises.explanation: Wrong word/linking verb. Corrected: The flowers smell so nice.

exercises.sentence: The food tastes well.
exercises.explanation: Requires adjective to describe state of being. Corrected: The food tastes good.

exercises.sentence: The girls were exited about the trip.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: The girls were excited about the trip.

exercises.sentence: The hen laid an egg.
exercises.explanation: Correct syntax.

exercises.sentence: The jury has reached a verdict.
exercises.explanation: Jury treated singular.

exercises.sentence: The movie was very bored.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: The movie was very boring.

exercises.sentence: The number of students are increasing.
exercises.explanation: Subject-verb agreement. "Number" is singular in this context. Corrected: The number of students is increasing.

exercises.sentence: The numbers of cars is increasing.
exercises.explanation: Numbers is plural. Corrected: The numbers of cars are increasing.

exercises.sentence: The pizza smelled deliciously.
exercises.explanation: Use "delicious" after a linking verb that describes state of being. Corrected: The pizza smelled delicious.

exercises.sentence: The price is different than I expected.
exercises.explanation: Correct the preposition "from". Corrected: The price is different from I expected.

exercises.sentence: The principle of the school is very nice.
exercises.explanation: Correct sentence.

exercises.sentence: The reason he's late is because he missed the bus.
exercises.explanation: Wordiness/redundancy. Corrected: The reason he's late is that he missed the bus. OR He's late because he missed the bus.

exercises.sentence: The reason is because I wanted to see you.
exercises.explanation: Redundant. Corrected: The reason is that I wanted to see you.

exercises.sentence: The reason why he is late is because he overslept.
exercises.explanation: This is redundant. Corrected: The reason he is late is that he overslept, or He is late because he overslept.

exercises.sentence: The shirt fits to loose.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: The shirt fits too loose.

exercises.sentence: The store is opened until 9 PM.
exercises.explanation: The correct verb to use here is "open". Corrected: The store is open until 9 PM.

exercises.sentence: The students studied good for the test.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: The students studied well for the test.

exercises.sentence: The sun rises in the east.
exercises.explanation: Correct verb usage.

exercises.sentence: The teacher gave the test back to he and I.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect pronoun case. Corrected: The teacher gave the test back to him and me.

exercises.sentence: The teacher learned us a new song.
exercises.explanation: Should be "taught". Corrected: The teacher taught us a new song.

exercises.sentence: The teachers, Mr. Jones, are great.
exercises.explanation: Subject-verb agreement error. The subject is "teacher," which is singular. Corrected: The teacher, Mr. Jones, is great.

exercises.sentence: The team are playing well.
exercises.explanation: Collective nouns can take singular or plural verbs. Team is singular in this instance. Corrected: The team is playing well.

exercises.sentence: The team have won the championship.
exercises.explanation: Correct subject-verb agreement. Corrected: The team has won the championship.

exercises.sentence: The weather is much more hotter today than yesterday.
exercises.explanation: Redundant comparison. Corrected: The weather is much hotter today than yesterday.

exercises.sentence: The weather is quit nice today.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: The weather is quite nice today.

exercises.sentence: The whether is nice today.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage; whether vs. weather. Corrected: The weather is nice today.

exercises.sentence: Their coming to visit.
exercises.explanation: Wrong word use. Corrected: They're coming to visit.

exercises.sentence: Their going to the store now.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect use of "their". Corrected: They're going to the store now.

exercises.sentence: Their house is very big.
exercises.explanation: Correct usage of possessive pronoun "their".

exercises.sentence: Their my best friends.
exercises.explanation: Wrong word use. Corrected: They're my best friends.

exercises.sentence: There are many people here.
exercises.explanation: Correct sentence.

exercises.sentence: There are two many apples in the basket.
exercises.explanation: Wrong word usage ("too" vs. "two"). Corrected: There are too many apples in the basket.

exercises.sentence: There cat is sleeping on the mat.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: Their cat is sleeping on the mat.

exercises.sentence: There going to be a party tonight.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: They're going to be a party tonight.

exercises.sentence: There going to the game tonight.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: They're going to the game tonight.

exercises.sentence: There is a cat on the roof.
exercises.explanation: Correct use of "there" indicating a place.

exercises.sentence: There is less water than usual in the lake.
exercises.explanation: Less is acceptable for quantity.

exercises.sentence: There is no milk left.
exercises.explanation: Correct.

exercises.sentence: There is only one slice of cake left.
exercises.explanation: Correct sentence.

exercises.sentence: They are affect by the weather.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage; affect vs. effect. Corrected: They are affected by the weather.

exercises.sentence: They are always late.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: They are always loosing there keys.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: They are always losing their keys.

exercises.sentence: They are coming to visit to they're friend.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: They are coming to visit their friend.

exercises.sentence: They are crying.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: They are different as me.
exercises.explanation: Corrected word "from." Corrected: They are different from me.

exercises.sentence: They are dreaming.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: They are exited to go to the concert.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: They are excited to go to the concert.

exercises.sentence: They are going to the beach.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: They are going to there house.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: They are going to their house.

exercises.sentence: They are my friends.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: They are playing soccer.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: They are wanting a new car.
exercises.explanation: Stative verb issue; "want" isn't typically used in the continuous. Corrected: They want a new car.

exercises.sentence: They are watching TV.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: They are working hard.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: They did well on the test hardly studying at all.
exercises.explanation: Word usage. Corrected: They did well on the test, hardly studying at all.

exercises.sentence: They has a big house.
exercises.explanation: Subject-verb agreement error. Corrected: They have a big house.

exercises.sentence: They have trouble finding they're way.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: They have trouble finding their way.

exercises.sentence: They have went to the store.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect verb form. Corrected: They have gone to the store.

exercises.sentence: They have went to the zoo.
exercises.explanation: Wrong verb form. Corrected: They have gone to the zoo.

exercises.sentence: They is coming to the party.
exercises.explanation: Subject-verb agreement error. Corrected: They are coming to the party.

exercises.sentence: They is coming to visit us.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect subject-verb agreement. Corrected: They are coming to visit us.

exercises.sentence: They should of studied harder.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect use of "of" instead of "have". Corrected: They should have studied harder.

exercises.sentence: They stoped smoking.
exercises.explanation: Valid construction.

exercises.sentence: They stopped to smoke.
exercises.explanation: Valid construction.

exercises.sentence: They was happy to see us.
exercises.explanation: Subject-verb agreement error. Corrected: They were happy to see us.

exercises.sentence: They was playing in the park.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect verb form. Corrected: They were playing in the park.

exercises.sentence: They went to they're house.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect possessive pronoun. Corrected: They went to their house.

exercises.sentence: They're dog is very friendly.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: Their dog is very friendly.

exercises.sentence: They're going to the store.
exercises.explanation: Correct usage of the contraction "they're".

exercises.sentence: They're happy to be here.
exercises.explanation: Correct sentence.

exercises.sentence: They're is a problem with the car.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word choice. Corrected: There is a problem with the car.

exercises.sentence: They're is no more milk.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect use of "they're". Corrected: There is no more milk.

exercises.sentence: They're were many people at the concert.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: There were many people at the concert.

exercises.sentence: This book is hers and mines.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect pronoun usage. Corrected: This book is hers and mine.

exercises.sentence: This house is theirs.
exercises.explanation: Correct sentence.

exercises.sentence: This is a really good book.
exercises.explanation: Grammar and syntax.

exercises.sentence: This is a unique situation.
exercises.explanation: Correct, since unique sounds like you-neek.

exercises.sentence: This is between you and I.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect pronoun case. Corrected: This is between you and me.

exercises.sentence: This is the best cake I ever ate.
exercises.explanation: Time agreement problem. Corrected: This is the best cake I have ever eaten.

exercises.sentence: To understand this you have to practice a lot.
exercises.explanation: Correct syntax.

exercises.sentence: To, too, and two, they are all homophones.
exercises.explanation: Missing article. Corrected: To, too, and two are all homophones.

exercises.sentence: We are going to the park tomorrow.
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: We could of gone to the beach.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: We could have gone to the beach.

exercises.sentence: We like too eat pizza.
exercises.explanation: The correct form to use is "to". Corrected: We like to eat pizza.

exercises.sentence: We prefer coffee then tea.
exercises.explanation: Correct preposition. Corrected: We prefer coffee to tea.

exercises.sentence: We was going to the movies.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect subject-verb agreement. Corrected: We were going to the movies.

exercises.sentence: We went their for dinner.
exercises.explanation: Wrong word use. Corrected: We went there for dinner.

exercises.sentence: We went their yesterday.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect usage. Corrected: We went there yesterday.

exercises.sentence: We went too the beach yesterday.
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: We went to the beach yesterday.

exercises.sentence: We will meet each other at 8 PM.
exercises.explanation: The best to use the pronoun. Corrected: We will meet at 8 PM.

exercises.sentence: What time will you arrive at?
exercises.explanation: The preposition at is not necessary. Corrected: What time will you arrive?

exercises.sentence: Where do you live at?
exercises.explanation: Should be no preposition. Corrected: Where do you live?

exercises.sentence: Who are you talking to?
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: Who did you give it too?
exercises.explanation: Word choice and sentence problem. Corrected: To whom did you give it?

exercises.sentence: Who did you see?
exercises.explanation: This sentence is grammatically correct.

exercises.sentence: Who is at the door?
exercises.explanation: Correct use of "who" to inquire about a person.

exercises.sentence: Who is going too the party?
exercises.explanation: Incorrect word usage. Corrected: Who is going to the party?

exercises.sentence: Who's book is this?
exercises.explanation: Word confusion. Corrected: Whose book is this?

exercises.sentence: Who's is it?
exercises.explanation: Wrong word use. Corrected: Whose is it?

exercises.sentence: Whom did you see at the party?
exercises.explanation: Correct use of "whom" as the object of the verb.

exercises.sentence: Whose car is that?
exercises.explanation: Correct use of "whose" to indicate possession.

exercises.sentence: You should not talk loudly in the library.
exercises.explanation: Correct, could be simplified.

exercises.sentence: You should of taken the trash out yesterday.
exercises.explanation: Word choice. Corrected: You should have taken the trash out yesterday.

exercises.sentence: You was wrong.
exercises.explanation: Subject-verb agreement error. Corrected: You were wrong.

exercises.sentence: You're car is very nice.
exercises.explanation: Wrong word use. Corrected: Your car is very nice.

exercises.sentence: You're my best friend.
exercises.explanation: Correct usage of the contraction "you're".

exercises.sentence: Your book is on the table.
exercises.explanation: Correct usage of the possessive pronoun "your".

exercises.sentence: Your going to be late.
exercises.explanation: Contraction error. Corrected: You're going to be late.

exercises.sentence: Your the best.
exercises.explanation: Wrong word use. Corrected: You're the best.

exercises.sentence: I am going to the store tomorrow.
exercises.explanation: This sentence has correct grammar and tense usage.

exercises.sentence: He don't like pizza.
exercises.explanation: Should be 'He doesn't like pizza' - third person singular requires 'doesn't'

exercises.sentence: They are watching television now.
exercises.explanation: Correct use of present continuous tense.

exercises.sentence: I have been to Paris last year.
exercises.explanation: Should be 'I went to Paris last year' - use simple past for specific past time.

exercises.sentence: She has finished her homework already.
exercises.explanation: Correct use of present perfect tense.

exercises.sentence: The children is playing in the park.
exercises.explanation: Should be 'The children are playing' - plural subject requires 'are'

exercises.sentence: I enjoy to play tennis.
exercises.explanation: Should be 'I enjoy playing tennis' - 'enjoy' is followed by gerund

exercises.sentence: We have been waiting for an hour.
exercises.explanation: Correct use of present perfect continuous tense.

exercises.sentence: If I will see him, I will tell him.
exercises.explanation: Should be 'If I see him' - use simple present in if-clause

exercises.sentence: She asked me where I was going.
exercises.explanation: Correct use of reported speech.
